mods:mods.mods:abstract: Encloses an extract from his brother's letter expressing his pleasure at the formation of a National Bible Society and John Jay's enrollment as one of the vice-presidents. He himself laments that a man of Jay's stature is still under the influence of practices obtained "in the Antediluvian age" in his opinion on war. The law of retaliation was given by Moses, but with Christ came a new concept which prohibits the old violence. Does not agree that the Moral Law is "exactly the same now" as before the Flood. If so, we must question precepts of the Gospel which prohibit things allowed by the Patriarchs. Jay admits as unlawful those wars arising from culpable desires and designs; does not believe other causes have existed since the days of the Apostles. There is no specific description of war by the Savior, but his example, his doctrines, and his precepts put an end to all war. We are taught to do good for evil and to pray for those who wrong us. Jay says that peace among nations is highly desirable, and the way to produce it is to extend the influence of the Gospel. This is a frank acknowledgment of its efficacy. Every man who is completely under the influence of the Gospel is unable to shed blood; however, education, tradition, and the passions of our fallen nature draw a veil over the understanding and induce the belief that war in self-defense is warranted by Christianity. His friendship for Jay induces him to thus unfold his views; hopes he may be favored, "in the evening of thy day," with clearness of vision and the gifts and graces of the spirit.
